answers.answer: I had it with my first son, and not with my second, and I'm currently 9 weeks with my third, so don't know yet.  I controlled it up to the last 2 weeks with diet and then had to use glucose pills the last 2 weeks, and they induced me a week early and I had a healthy 7lb6oz boy:)  his blood sugar dropped once right after birth and they just gave him some sugar water and he never had an episode again. He is now 8 years old.  I ate 3 (30 Carb) meals and 3 (15 Carb) snacks a day all 2 1/2hours apart.  They should send you to a dietician to help you.  Good luck to you and feel free to ask me any questions:)

I had it with my first had to take the insulin. Everything whent well and he was born late and was a normal baby size. With my second I was not, which is rare as you are discovering. Anyways had a healthy baby girl. Then with my third, well I was a gain. It was not so great. We could not get my blood sugars under control.  I would go hypo and gels. It was dangerous. I could have ended up in a coma. So they induced me a month early, in order to prevent that from happening. Now im expecting again  im having my referal to the diabetes clinic right away. Im scared this time. Im hopeing that thing will be ok. Though im worried about it. Ive alreasy  started my diet.  Salads aand chicken.  Here is a tip that should help. Green veggies are called free bees as they do not affect your blood sugar and so you can eat as much as you want of it. Stay away from breads and fruits like bananas, pinaple, mango they will shoot uour sugars through the roof.

I didnt have it with my first two but do with this one. Luckily its maintained with diet ( i don't eat sweets or over kill since removal of my gallbladder two years ago) but my baby girl is doing perfectly.  Weight is normal besides the alarms for checking my blood sugar levels its been pretty normal.  My doctor even said i can carry to term instead of the induction a week early.  (Its a precaution so the baby doesnt get too big for birth resulting in c-section.) As long as you follow your doctor's advice you'll do great. For me my due date is important (its my grandmother's birthday and she passed two years a go.) The doctor was willing to hear me out and my wishes together we managed the gestational diabetes well. Best of luck to you. (Btw im 36 weeks today and going strong)
